articles.title: ğŸ” OWASP ZAP â€” Structured, Numbered Guide
articles.content:
# ğŸ” OWASP ZAP â€” Structured, Numbered Guide

**Purpose:** This document is organized into numbered sections. Each section contains:
- **What it is / Why it matters** â€” short conceptual explanation.  
- **Step-by-step commands** â€” runnable commands with safe defaults.  
- **What to expect** â€” typical output or behavior.  
- **Troubleshooting & tips** â€” common problems and fixes.  
- **Safety / ethics note** â€” when applicable.

---

## 1. What is OWASP ZAP?

**What it is / Why it matters**  
OWASP Zed Attack Proxy (ZAP) is a free, open-source web application security scanner maintained by the OWASP community. It helps developers and security testers automatically and manually find vulnerabilities in web apps and APIs.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Start ZAP GUI (Linux/macOS)
./zap.sh

Start ZAP headless (daemon)
./zap.sh -daemon -port 8080

Quick baseline scan (Docker example)
docker run -t owasp/zap2docker-stable zap-baseline.py -t https://example.com
```

**What to expect**  
A GUI opens for interactive testing or a headless run completes and produces a report (HTML/JSON) when finished.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If the GUI doesn't start, check Java installation and permissions. For headless runs, ensure network access from the container/host to the target.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Only test applications you own or have explicit authorization to test. Automated scans may be intrusive and affect availability.

---

## 2. Installation & Setup (Windows)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Installing ZAP on Windows gives you a desktop GUI for interactive testing and local automation.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```powershell
Install via Chocolatey (Windows)
choco install zap -y

Or download and run installer:
https://www.zaproxy.org/download/
Then run zap.bat to start
zap.bat -version
```

**What to expect**  
An installed program appears in Start Menu; `zap.bat -version` prints the version.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If proxy intercept doesn't work, import ZAP's root certificate into the browser. Run installer as Administrator to avoid permission issues.

**Safety / ethics note**  
When importing root certs, only do so on testing browsers or VMs to avoid trusting ZAP globally on production systems.

---

## 3. Installation & Setup (Linux)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Linux installations are useful for servers, CI runners, and testers who prefer Unix environments.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Install from package (Ubuntu/Debian; may be older)
sudo apt update
sudo apt install zaproxy -y

Or download latest release and run
wget https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/releases/download/v2.14.0/ZAP_2_14_0_Linux.tar.gz
tar -xzf ZAP_2_14_0_Linux.tar.gz
cd ZAP_2.14.0/
./zap.sh
```

**What to expect**  
`./zap.sh` starts the GUI; headless can be started via `-daemon`.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Ensure Java (OpenJDK) is installed and `JAVA_HOME` is correct. For Docker-based runs, map ports and mount volumes for reports.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Run ZAP in isolated environments when testing internet-facing targets to avoid accidental exposure.

---

## 4. Installation & Setup (macOS & Docker)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
macOS supports a native GUI via Homebrew; Docker offers reproducible headless runs for CI.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
macOS via Homebrew
brew install --cask owasp-zap

Docker (headless baseline scan)
docker pull owasp/zap2docker-stable
docker run -t owasp/zap2docker-stable zap-baseline.py -t https://example.com

Docker with GUI (webswing)
docker run -u zap -p 8080:8080 -p 8090:8090 -i owasp/zap2docker-stable zap-webswing.sh
```

**What to expect**  
Homebrew installs app bundle; Docker run prints CLI output and produces reports (zap-report.json/html).

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
When running Docker, mount a host directory to `/zap/wrk` to persist reports. Use `-e` env vars for API key if needed.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Avoid publishing Docker containers with embedded API keys or credentials.

---

## 5. Basic Workflow (GUI Mode)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
GUI mode offers visual tools (proxy, spider, active scan) ideal for manual testing and learning.

**Step-by-step commands**  
1. Start ZAP GUI: `./zap.sh` or open the app.  
2. Configure browser proxy: `localhost:8080`.  
3. Browse target to populate History.  
4. Right-click target â†’ `Attack` â†’ `Spider` or `Active Scan`.  

**What to expect**  
History tab fills with requests; passive scan results appear; active scan reports vulnerabilities.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If traffic doesn't show, confirm browser proxy settings and that the ZAP root cert is installed in the browser.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Use passive scan for production; active scan is intrusive and should be run in test or approved windows.

---

## 6. Command Line & Headless Usage

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Headless mode and CLI scripts enable automation in CI/CD and scheduled scanning without UI.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Start daemon with API key
./zap.sh -daemon -port 8080 -config api.key=YOUR_KEY

Baseline scan (Docker)
docker run -t owasp/zap2docker-stable zap-baseline.py -t https://example.com

Full scan
zap-full-scan.py -t https://example.com -r zap-full-report.html
```

**What to expect**  
CLI scripts run and generate reports (`.html`, `.json`) in working directory.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Use `-v` or verbose logs for debugging. Ensure the daemon has started before calling the API.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Schedule scans during low-traffic windows and only on authorized targets.

---

## 7. Proxy Configuration & Browser Setup

**What it is / Why it matters**  
ZAP acts as an intercepting proxy; proper proxy setup is essential to capture and modify traffic.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```text
Browser proxy:
Host: localhost
Port: 8080

Chrome example:
chrome --proxy-server="localhost:8080"
```

**What to expect**  
Requests from browser are routed through ZAP and appear in History.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Install ZAP CA certificate (Tools â†’ Options â†’ Dynamic SSL Certificates) in browser to avoid TLS errors.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Only install ZAP certs in test browsers/VMs; remove certs after testing.

---

## 8. Automated Scanning â€” Spider & AJAX Spider

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Spiders discover URLs and parameters; the AJAX spider explores JavaScript-driven content that a traditional spider may miss.

**Step-by-step commands**  
1. Right-click target â†’ `Attack` â†’ `Spider` â†’ Start.  
2. Tools â†’ `AJAX Spider` â†’ Enter start URL â†’ Start.  

**What to expect**  
New endpoints and parameters are added to the Site Tree/History for further scanning.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
AJAX Spider requires a browser launcher (headless browser). Configure crawl depth and scope to limit noise.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Keep crawl scope tight to avoid crawling entire external domains or directories.

---

## 9. Active & Passive Scanning

**What it is / Why it matters**  
- Passive scanning inspects proxied traffic without sending extra requests â€” safe for production.  
- Active scanning performs vulnerability checks and may be intrusive.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```text
Passive scan: happens automatically as you proxy traffic
Active scan:
Right-click target â†’ Attack â†’ Active Scan â†’ Configure policy â†’ Start
```

**What to expect**  
Passive scan lists informational issues; active scan generates detailed alerts with risk levels.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Customize scan policy (Analyze â†’ Scan Policy Manager) to tune checks and reduce false positives.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Run active scans only with permission and preferably in staging environments.

---

## 10. Manual Testing: Intercepting, Breakpoints & Fuzzing

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Manual tools let testers craft requests, manipulate parameters, and fuzz endpoints to validate vulnerabilities.

**Step-by-step commands**  
1. Proxies â†’ Main Proxy â†’ Enable intercept.  
2. Browse target; requests pause for review.  
3. Right-click a parameter â†’ Fuzz â†’ Add payloads â†’ Start.

**What to expect**  
Intercepted requests appear for modification; fuzz results show responses and potential crashes or anomalies.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Use small payload sets first. Inspect response codes, content length, and response times for anomalies.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Fuzzing can cause instability â€” avoid on production unless explicitly allowed.

---

## 11. Authentication & Session Management

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Configuring authentication allows ZAP to maintain sessions and scan authenticated areas of an app.

**Step-by-step commands**  
1. Create Context â†’ Include URLs in the context.  
2. Context â†’ Authentication â†’ Choose method (Form-based/HTTP/Script).  
3. Add User â†’ Provide credentials â†’ Test login.

**What to expect**  
ZAP can log in as that user, maintain session tokens, and scan protected areas.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Use cookie/session token handling and anti-CSRF configuration so ZAP can refresh tokens during scans.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Use test accounts with limited privileges and follow data handling rules.

---

## 12. API & CI/CD Integration

**What it is / Why it matters**  
ZAP's API and Docker images enable integration into pipelines (Jenkins, GitHub Actions) for automated security checks.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
# Start daemon with API key
./zap.sh -daemon -port 8080 -config api.key=mykey

API example: start spider (curl)
curl "http://localhost:8080/JSON/spider/action/scan/?url=https://example.com&apikey=mykey"

GitHub Action example (uses zaproxy/action-baseline)
uses: zaproxy/action-baseline@v0.7.0
with:
  target: 'https://example.com'
```

**What to expect**  
Pipeline jobs run ZAP scans and publish artifacts (zap-report.json/html). Fail builds on policy violations if configured.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Pin Docker image versions in CI to ensure reproducibility. Increase timeouts for large apps.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Restrict CI runners' network access; ensure reports do not leak secrets or PII.

---

## 13. Reporting (HTML, XML, JSON)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
ZAP can generate human- and machine-readable reports for remediation and compliance.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Generate HTML report (CLI)
zap-full-scan.py -t https://example.com -r zap-report.html

Export alerts via API (JSON)
curl "http://localhost:8080/JSON/core/view/alerts/?apikey=mykey"
```

**What to expect**  
Reports contain alerts grouped by risk and include request/response evidence and remediation advice.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Filter alerts by context or severity before generating executive reports. Sanitize reports to remove sensitive data.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Protect generated reports; they contain exploit evidence and potentially sensitive data.

---

## 14. Add-ons & Extensions

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Add-ons extend ZAP's capabilities (e.g., Advanced SQLi, DOM XSS, GraphQL, OpenAPI support).

**Step-by-step commands**  
1. Manage Add-ons â†’ Marketplace â†’ Search and Install.  
2. Restart ZAP if required.

**What to expect**  
New menu options, scanners, or importers become available.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Keep add-ons updated; some may depend on Java versions or other add-ons.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Review add-on permissions and source; avoid installing untrusted third-party plugins.

---

## 15. Custom Scripting

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Scripts let you automate tasks, implement custom scanning logic, or tweak requests/responses.

**Step-by-step commands**  
1. Script Console â†’ New Script â†’ Choose type (Proxy/Active/Passive).  
2. Write JS/Python/Groovy script and save.  
3. Enable script and test.

**What to expect**  
Scripts run inline and can modify traffic, implement auth flows, or add checks.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Test scripts in small scope first. Use logging in scripts to debug behavior.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Scripts can introduce unsafe behavior; review and sandbox them before enabling.

---

## 16. Troubleshooting & Performance Tuning

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Common issues include certificate errors, memory limits, and slow scans. Proper tuning improves reliability.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```text
Increase Java heap (edit zap.sh or zap.bat)
Example JVM option:
-Xmx4g
```

**What to expect**  
Larger heap reduces OOM errors for big scans. Tuning threads and delays balances speed and server load.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If certificate errors occur, regenerate and reinstall ZAP CA cert. If Docker can't reach target, check network mode and proxy settings.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Avoid increasing concurrency against production systems â€” prioritize stability.

---

## 17. Common Use Cases & Workflows

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Practical scenarios: dev-shift-left testing, pre-prod scans, API testing, pentests, and CI gates.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```text
CI baseline scan (Docker) for a PR:
docker run -t owasp/zap2docker-stable zap-baseline.py -t ${TARGET_URL} -J zap-report.json
```

**What to expect**  
Automated scan in PR provides pass/fail signal and report artifacts for reviewers.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Use contexts to limit scan scope. Exclude 3rd-party domains and known safe endpoints.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Coordinate with teams to avoid disrupting testing or deployments.

---

## 18. Pro Tips & Best Practices

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Actionable advice to get accurate results and minimise false positives/negatives.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```text
Example starter scan
zap-baseline.py -t https://example.com -r baseline.html

Use contexts and users for authenticated scans
Use scripts to handle anti-CSRF tokens
```

**What to expect**  
Cleaner results, fewer false positives, and repeatable scans.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Tune scan policies, whitelist static resources, and use manual verification to confirm findings.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Keep test scopes narrow and document approvals.

---

## 19. Legal Disclaimer

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Legal constraints and ethics for security testing.

**Step-by-step commands**  
N/A â€” read policies and obtain approvals.

**What to expect**  
Authorization processes, NDAs, and rules of engagement when testing thirdâ€‘party or production systems.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If unsure about scope, pause testing and request written confirmation.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Unauthorized testing may violate laws and cause service outages. Always act responsibly.

---

**End of file**

name: sqlmap
description: Automates detecting and exploiting SQL injection flaws.

articles.title: âš¡ SQLMap â€” Structured, Numbered Guide
articles.content:
# âš¡ SQLMap â€” Structured, Numbered Guide 

**Purpose:** This file is organized into numbered sections. Each section contains:
- **What it is / Why it matters** â€” short conceptual explanation.  
- **Step-by-step commands** â€” runnable commands with safe defaults.  
- **What to expect** â€” typical output or behavior.  
- **Troubleshooting & tips** â€” common problems and fixes.  
- **Safety / ethics note** â€” when applicable.

---

## 1. What is SQLMap?

**What it is / Why it matters**  
SQLMap is an open-source automation tool for detecting and exploiting SQL injection (SQLi) vulnerabilities. It helps penetration testers and security researchers quickly enumerate databases, extract data, and â€” with authorization â€” demonstrate the impact of SQLi on target systems.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Show help / basic usage
sqlmap --help
```

**What to expect**  
Help text listing options and examples. A local executable that responds to `-u` target flags.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If `sqlmap` isn't found, ensure PATH is set or run `python sqlmap.py` from the cloned repo.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Only test systems you own or have written permission to test. Unauthorized SQLi is illegal.

---

## 2. Installation & Setup

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Installing the latest stable SQLMap gives you the newest detection engines and tamper scripts. On Kali it's preinstalled; on other Linux distributions, install from package manager or GitHub.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Debian/Ubuntu via apt (may be older)
sudo apt update && sudo apt install sqlmap -y

Clone latest from GitHub (recommended)
git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/sqlmapproject/sqlmap.git sqlmap-dev
cd sqlmap-dev
Run using Python
python3 sqlmap.py --help
```

**What to expect**  
A working `sqlmap` script in the `sqlmap-dev` folder; `--help` prints usage.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If Python complains, install `python3` and dependencies. Use virtualenv for isolation.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Keep the repo up-to-date; do not use precompiled binaries from untrusted sources.

---

## 3. Basic Usage & Syntax

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Defines how to pass targets, parameters, and request options to SQLMap â€” the foundation of safe, repeatable testing.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Basic GET test
python3 sqlmap.py -u "http://example.com/page.php?id=1"

Test specific parameter
python3 sqlmap.py -u "http://example.com/page.php?id=1&name=test" -p id

POST data
python3 sqlmap.py -u "http://example.com/login.php" --data="username=admin&password=pass"
```

**What to expect**  
SQLMap runs tests, prints progress, and reports detected injection types and evidence.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Start with `--level=1 --risk=1` to minimize impact; increase only when necessary.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Use `--batch` with caution; it removes interactive confirmation and can cause destructive actions.

---

## 4. Request Options (Headers, Cookies, Proxy)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Allows customizing HTTP requests to match application behavior and bypass trivial protections.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Custom headers
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --headers="X-Forwarded-For: 127.0.0.1"

Cookies
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --cookie="PHPSESSID=abc123; user=admin"

Proxy (Burp)
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --proxy="http://127.0.0.1:8080"
```

**What to expect**  
SQLMap routes traffic via proxy or includes headers/cookies in each request.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
When testing behind WAFs, use Burp to inspect requests. Use `--random-agent` to rotate UA strings.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Do not leak sensitive cookies or credentials. Use test accounts where possible.

---

## 5. Detection Techniques (Levels & Risk)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
`--level` and `--risk` control the aggressiveness of tests. Understanding them avoids unnecessary disruption.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Default gentle scan
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --level=1 --risk=1

More aggressive (more tests)
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --level=5 --risk=3
```

**What to expect**  
Higher levels/risk increase the number of payloads and the chance of noticeable effects (slower responses, DB modifications).

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If the app is unstable, reduce `--level`/`--risk`. Use `--timeout` and `--delay` to reduce load.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Aggressive scans can trigger alarms or cause outages; get explicit permission.

---

## 6. Specific Techniques

**What it is / Why it matters**  
SQLMap supports Boolean, Error, Union, Stacked, and Time-based techniques â€” choose based on DB and behavior.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Boolean-based blind
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --technique=B

Error-based
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --technique=E

Time-based
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --technique=T
```

**What to expect**  
SQLMap will attempt the selected technique, show payloads, and report evidence if successful.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If one technique fails, try `--technique=BEUST` to let SQLMap try multiple approaches.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Time-based tests can be noisy and slow; avoid on production without consent.

---

## 7. Database Enumeration (Banner, Users, DBs, Tables)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Enumeration reveals target DBMS, users, databases, tables â€” essential for informed exploitation and reporting.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Banner and basic info
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --banner --current-user --current-db

List databases
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --dbs

List tables
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" -D target_db --tables

List columns
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" -D target_db -T users --columns
```

**What to expect**  
SQLMap outputs DBMS type, current user, and lists of databases/tables/columns when found.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Use `--threads` to speed extraction but monitor server load. Use `--hex` for non-printable characters.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Enumeration may expose sensitive data in clear text â€” handle outputs securely.

---

## 8. Data Extraction & Dumping

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Dumping demonstrates the severity of vulnerabilities by extracting data (only with authorization).

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Dump entire DB
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" -D target_db --dump

Dump a single table
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" -D target_db -T users --dump

Dump selected columns
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" -D target_db -T users -C "username,password" --dump
```

**What to expect**  
CSV-like output saved under `./output/<target>/` with extracted rows.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If dumping stalls, use `--dump-all --threads=2` or `--start`/`--stop` to page results.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Never exfiltrate or share real sensitive data. Sanitize outputs in reports and follow disclosure policies.

---

## 9. Advanced Exploitation (File System & OS Access)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
SQLMap can read/write files and attempt OS command execution â€” powerful for demonstrating full compromise.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Read file
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --file-read="/etc/passwd"

Write file (upload)
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --file-write="shell.php" --file-dest="/var/www/html/shell.php"

Execute OS command
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --os-cmd="whoami"

Interactive OS shell (if possible)
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --os-shell
```

**What to expect**  
`--file-read` prints file content; `--file-write` attempts to upload; OS commands print output.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Use `--tmp-path` for writeable locations. If `--os-shell` fails, try `--os-pwn` only in controlled labs.

**Safety / ethics note**  
OS-level access is extremely invasive â€” only with explicit consent and documented scope.

---

## 10. Evasion Techniques (Tamper Scripts & Delays)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Tamper scripts and timing control help bypass WAFs and input filters while reducing detection.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
List tamper scripts
python3 sqlmap.py --list-tampers

Use tamper scripts
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --tamper=space2comment,charencode

Add delays
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --delay=2 --randomize
```

**What to expect**  
Modified payloads in requests and slower, stealthier traffic patterns.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Test tamper scripts in a proxy (Burp) to understand how payloads change. Combine with `--technique` selection.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Evasion can be mistaken for malicious intent by defenders â€” record test approvals.

---

## 11. Session Management & Output Options

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Sessions let you resume scans; output directories organize results for reporting and evidence preservation.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Save session
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" -s session.sqlite

Load session and resume
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" -s session.sqlite --flush-session

Set output directory and verbosity
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --output-dir=/tmp/sqlmap_output -v 3
```

**What to expect**  
Session files under `--output-dir`; verbose logs and `traffic.log` if `-t` used.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Use `--batch` for automation but keep separate sessions per target.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Protect session files â€” they may contain sensitive request payloads and cookies.

---

## 12. Burp Suite Integration

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Burp captures complex requests and allows fine inspection; SQLMap can consume saved requests and proxy through Burp.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Use saved request file from Burp
python3 sqlmap.py -r request.txt -p username

Route via Burp proxy
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --proxy="http://127.0.0.1:8080"
```

**What to expect**  
SQLMap shows the same HTTP traffic Burp captured and targets chosen parameters.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Ensure `request.txt` uses correct CRLF formatting. Use `--ignore-proxy` for hosts you don't want proxied.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Avoid storing sensitive credentials in public repos; secure Burp project files.

---

## 13. Automation & Batch Processing

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Automating scans helps in large assessments but increases risk â€” use controlled scripts with logging and throttling.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Multiple targets
python3 sqlmap.py -m urls.txt --batch

Crawl forms
python3 sqlmap.py -u "http://example.com" --crawl=2 --forms
```

**What to expect**  
Batch runs non-interactively; crawl finds form parameters to test.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Monitor resource use and throttle with `--delay` and `--timeout`.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Automated scans should be in-scope and scheduled to avoid business hours impact.

---

## 14. Database-Specific Features

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Tailoring commands to DBMS improves success rates and reduces noise.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
MySQL
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --dbms=mysql --privileges

PostgreSQL
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --dbms=postgresql --file-write="shell.php" --file-dest="/tmp/shell.php"

MSSQL
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --dbms=mssql --os-shell
```

**What to expect**  
DBMS-specific payloads and enumeration options are used; some features (UDF injection) require advanced privileges.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
If DBMS misidentified, force `--dbms` to speed tests. Use `--os-cmd` only when confirmed possible.

**Safety / ethics note**  
DBMS exploitation may modify data â€” take DB snapshots where possible.

---

## 15. Common Testing Scenarios (Login, Search, APIs)

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Examples reflect real world vectors: login forms, search inputs, REST APIs. They help testers apply SQLMap safely.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Login form (POST)
python3 sqlmap.py -u "http://example.com/login.php" --data="username=admin&password=pass" --level=3 --risk=2

Search parameter
python3 sqlmap.py -u "http://example.com/search.php?q=test" -p q --technique=BEUST

API endpoint with JSON body (use Burp saved request)
python3 sqlmap.py -r request.txt --batch
```

**What to expect**  
SQLMap identifies injectable parameters and recommends next steps (enumeration/dump).

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
For JSON APIs, prefer `-r` saved request. Test with safe `--batch` flags in non-destructive modes first.

**Safety / ethics note**  
APIs often handle sensitive data; minimize exposure and follow disclosure protocols.

---

## 16. Pro Tips & Best Practices

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Guidance to make testing efficient, safe, and defensible.

**Step-by-step commands**  
```bash
Recommended starter
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --level=1 --risk=1 -v 2

If WAF present, test tamper scripts via proxy
python3 sqlmap.py -u "URL" --tamper=space2comment --proxy="http://127.0.0.1:8080"
```

**What to expect**  
Safer initial scans, clearer logs, and repeatable testing steps.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
Document everything, store outputs securely, and use `--threads` conservatively.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Obtain written authorization, follow responsible disclosure, and never exfiltrate data unnecessarily.

---

## 17. Legal Disclaimer

**What it is / Why it matters**  
Legal and ethical constraints around using SQLMap.

**Step-by-step commands**  
N/A â€” read and follow organizational policies.

**What to expect**  
Compliance requirements and potential legal consequences for unauthorized testing.

**Troubleshooting & tips**  
When in doubt, pause and obtain written authorization.

**Safety / ethics note**  
Unauthorized use may violate laws and lead to criminal charges. Always act ethically.

---

**End of file**

articles.title: ğŸ•’ Plaso (log2timeline) â€” Complete Forensics Timeline Analysis Guide
articles.content:
# ğŸ•’ Plaso (log2timeline) â€” Complete Forensics Timeline Analysis Guide

## 1ï¸âƒ£ What is Plaso?
Plaso (**Plaso Langar AÃ° Safna Ã–llu**) is a Python-based engine used for automatic creation of **super timelines**. It extracts timestamps from multiple file formats and system artifacts, making it invaluable for **digital forensics, incident response, and timeline reconstruction**.

Plaso allows investigators to reconstruct **who did what, and when**, during a security event.

---

## 2ï¸âƒ£ Installation & Setup

### ğŸ§ Ubuntu / Debian
```bash
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:gift/stable
sudo apt update
sudo apt install plaso-tools
log2timeline.py --version
psort.py --version
```

### ğŸ§± CentOS / RHEL / Fedora
```bash
sudo yum install epel-release
sudo yum install python3-pip python3-devel
sudo pip3 install plaso
log2timeline.py --version
```

### ğŸªŸ Windows
```bash
Download from: https://github.com/log2timeline/plaso/releases
log2timeline.py --version
psort.py --version
```

### ğŸ macOS
```bash
pip3 install plaso
or
brew install plaso
log2timeline.py --version
```

---

## 3ï¸âƒ£ Basic Usage

### Create a Timeline
```bash
log2timeline.py timeline.plaso /path/to/evidence
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w timeline.csv timeline.plaso
```

### Examples
```bash
log2timeline.py timeline.plaso disk_image.dd
log2timeline.py timeline.plaso /path/to/dir/
log2timeline.py timeline.plaso file1.log file2.evtx
log2timeline.py --workers 4 timeline.plaso disk_image.dd
```

---

## 4ï¸âƒ£ Timeline Output Formats
```bash
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w timeline.csv timeline.plaso
psort.py -o json -w timeline.json timeline.plaso
psort.py -o sqlite -w timeline.db timeline.plaso
psort.py -o elastic -w timeline timeline.plaso
```

---

## 5ï¸âƒ£ Advanced Timeline Analysis

### Filter Examples
```bash
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w filtered.csv --date-filter "2023-06-01,2023-06-30" timeline.plaso
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w filtered.csv --parsers "winevtx,prefetch,mft" timeline.plaso
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w filtered.csv --slice "malware" timeline.plaso
```

### Parser Management
```bash
log2timeline.py --parsers list
log2timeline.py --parsers "winevtx,prefetch,mft" timeline.plaso disk_image.dd
log2timeline.py --parsers "!syslog,!apache" timeline.plaso disk_image.dd
```

---

## 6ï¸âƒ£ Performance Optimization
```bash
log2timeline.py --workers 8 timeline.plaso disk_image.dd
log2timeline.py --buffer-size 196608 timeline.plaso disk_image.dd
log2timeline.py --temporary-directory /tmp/plaso timeline.plaso disk_image.dd
```

---

## 7ï¸âƒ£ Forensic Investigation Workflows

### ğŸªŸ Windows Analysis
```bash
log2timeline.py --parsers "winevtx,winreg,prefetch,mft,lnk,pe,olecf" --workers 4 windows_timeline.plaso windows_image.dd
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w windows_timeline.csv windows_timeline.plaso
```

### ğŸ§ Linux Analysis
```bash
log2timeline.py --parsers "syslog,utmp,bash_history,sqlite" --workers 4 linux_timeline.plaso linux_image.dd
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w linux_timeline.csv linux_timeline.plaso
```

---

## 8ï¸âƒ£ Timeline Analysis Techniques

### Event Correlation
```bash
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w detailed_timeline.csv --additional-fields "inode,username,hostname" timeline.plaso
```

### Anomaly Detection
```bash
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w after_hours.csv --date-filter "*T22:00:00,*T06:00:00" timeline.plaso
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w weekend_activity.csv --date-filter "2023-06-17,2023-06-18" timeline.plaso
```

---

## 9ï¸âƒ£ Automation Scripts

### Bash Batch Script
```bash
!/bin/bash
EVIDENCE_DIR="$1"
OUTPUT_DIR="$2"
CASE_NAME="$3"
log2timeline.py --workers 4 "$OUTPUT_DIR/${CASE_NAME}.plaso" "$EVIDENCE_DIR"
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w "$OUTPUT_DIR/${CASE_NAME}.csv" "$OUTPUT_DIR/${CASE_NAME}.plaso"
```

### Python Script Integration
```python
import subprocess
subprocess.run(["log2timeline.py", "timeline.plaso", "/evidence/path"])
subprocess.run(["psort.py", "-o", "l2tcsv", "-w", "timeline.csv", "timeline.plaso"])
```

---

## ğŸ”Ÿ Integration with Other Tools

### ğŸ§  Volatility
```bash
vol -f memory.dmp --profile=Win7SP1x64 timeliner --output-file=volatility_timeline.body
log2timeline.py combined_timeline.plaso disk_image.dd
```

### ğŸ§° Autopsy
```bash
log2timeline.py autopsy_timeline.plaso /path/to/autopsy/case/
psort.py -o l2tcsv -w plaso_timeline.csv autopsy_timeline.plaso
```

### ğŸ“Š ELK Stack
```bash
psort.py -o elastic --server localhost --port 9200 --index-name forensic_timeline timeline.plaso
```

---

## 1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£ Troubleshooting

### Common Problems
```bash
log2timeline.py --buffer-size 65536 timeline.plaso large_image.dd
log2timeline.py --no-vss timeline.plaso corrupted_image.dd
log2timeline.py --parsers "!sqlite,!chrome" timeline.plaso image.dd
```

### Performance
```bash
log2timeline.py --workers $(nproc) timeline.plaso image.dd
log2timeline.py --temporary-directory /tmp/ramdisk timeline.plaso image.dd
```

---

## 1ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£ Use Cases

### Digital Forensics
- Criminal investigation timelines  
- User activity reconstruction  
- File access and modification history

### Incident Response
- Malware execution tracking  
- Privilege escalation timeline  
- Persistence analysis

### Compliance & Auditing
- Access audits  
- Data exfiltration timeline  
- Insider threat tracking

---

## 1ï¸âƒ£3ï¸âƒ£ Pro Tips & Best Practices
âœ… Use targeted parsers only (`--parsers`)  
âœ… Always verify time zones (`--output-time-zone UTC`)  
âœ… Combine multiple sources (memory + disk)  
âœ… Regularly update Plaso (`pip3 install -U plaso`)  
âœ… Visualize with Kibana or Timesketch  

---

## âš–ï¸ Legal Disclaimer
Plaso must be used **only on systems you own or have permission to analyze**. Unauthorized forensic analysis can violate privacy or computer misuse laws. Always maintain chain of custody and follow organizational and legal policies.
